lexUnit.name: infuriated.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: filled with rage and anger

sentence.text: A gang of local ruffians was passing by and , when they saw what was happening , became infuriated against Richard Baxter .
The bull tossed the effigy out of their hands and became very infuriated . "
I go along and watch women 's football and get really infuriated to see a man out there refereeing the game , and often in a very condescending manner !
The sources said he is infuriated with her after a row that erupted last week , and is likely to distance himself from her .
I was suddenly infuriated at the thought of what we had believed about the Germans in England .
I was even more infuriated to read that their short separation was a ` tragedy " .
In England wild storms swept the country , and commuters were infuriated and inconvenienced by the ASLEF dispute .
And while she sounded sympathetic , she was in reality infuriated with Doreen .
His teachers were suspicious of his popularity , annoyed by his lack of interest in academic work and infuriated that he could still achieve high marks in examinations .
The infuriated Milan Cardinal told the city governor that both the Chief of Police and the governor would be excommunicated if Landriani was not immediately released back to the convent .

An infuriated Charles ordered the battering of Newgate , where artillery breached the wall and hit the nearby Carmelite house ( now Whitefriars Museum where Civil War will be displayed ) supposedly killing two of the occupants .
I am spell-bound by the sound of French , infuriated when I ca n't read it in the books I am given .
` Then you can do so today -- at the barbecue , " Lucy hissed , suddenly infuriated with them both , although more so with Silas than with Doreen .
` I 'm infuriated with myself , " he gritted from behind clenched teeth , his scowl deepening .
Lady followed her example rather than suffer at the hands of her infuriated master .
Matilda looked right back into the flashing eyes of this infuriated female giant and said with total calmness , ` I have not moved away from my desk , Miss Trunchbull , since the lesson began .
In Oviedo an infuriated mob was only prevented from lynching the distinguished poet Meléndez Valdés by the appearance of priests with the exposed host .
